synsets.definition: an open-source container orchestration platform for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications
examples: We deployed our microservices to Kubernetes
The Kubernetes cluster handles auto-scaling

synsets.definition: a platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers, providing OS-level virtualization
examples: Build the Docker image with docker build
Docker containers are lightweight and portable

synsets.definition: a lightweight, standalone, executable package that includes everything needed to run an application: code, runtime, system tools, and libraries
examples: Each microservice runs in its own container
Containers provide consistent environments across development and production

synsets.definition: the smallest deployable unit in Kubernetes, consisting of one or more containers that share storage and network resources
examples: Each pod has its own IP address
The pod contains both the application and sidecar containers

synsets.definition: an infrastructure as code tool by HashiCorp that lets you define cloud and on-prem resources in declarative configuration files
examples: Use terraform apply to provision the infrastructure
Terraform manages the state of your cloud resources

synsets.definition: an open-source automation tool for configuration management, application deployment, and task automation using YAML playbooks
examples: Run the Ansible playbook to configure the servers
Ansible uses SSH to connect to managed nodes

synsets.definition: an infrastructure as code platform that allows defining cloud resources using general-purpose programming languages like Python, TypeScript, and Go
examples: Pulumi lets you use real programming languages instead of DSLs
Deploy with pulumi up

synsets.definition: an AWS service for modeling and provisioning AWS resources using YAML or JSON templates
examples: Deploy the CloudFormation stack to create the VPC
CloudFormation handles resource dependencies automatically

synsets.definition: Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud, a web service providing resizable compute capacity in the cloud as virtual servers
examples: Launch an EC2 instance to host the application
EC2 instances can be scaled based on demand

synsets.definition: Amazon Simple Storage Service, an object storage service offering scalability, availability, and security for data storage
examples: Upload the files to S3
S3 buckets can be configured with versioning

synsets.definition: AWS Lambda, a serverless compute service that runs code in response to events without provisioning or managing servers
examples: The Lambda function processes S3 uploads
Lambda scales automatically based on incoming requests

synsets.definition: Amazon Relational Database Service, a managed database service supporting multiple database engines including PostgreSQL, MySQL, and Aurora
examples: Create an RDS instance for the production database
RDS handles backups and patching automatically

synsets.definition: a fully managed NoSQL database service by AWS providing fast and predictable performance with seamless scalability
examples: DynamoDB tables scale automatically
Use DynamoDB for low-latency data access

synsets.definition: AWS Identity and Access Management, a service for securely controlling access to AWS resources through users, groups, roles, and policies
examples: Create an IAM role for the Lambda function
IAM policies define who can access what resources

synsets.definition: Virtual Private Cloud, an isolated virtual network within a cloud provider where you can launch resources in a defined network
examples: Create a VPC with public and private subnets
The VPC provides network isolation for your workloads

synsets.definition: Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service, a managed Kubernetes service that simplifies running Kubernetes on AWS
examples: Deploy the application to EKS
EKS manages the Kubernetes control plane

synsets.definition: Amazon Elastic Container Service, a fully managed container orchestration service for running Docker containers on AWS
examples: Run the containers on ECS Fargate
ECS tasks define the container configuration

synsets.definition: a serverless compute engine for containers that works with both ECS and EKS, eliminating the need to manage servers
examples: Run containers on Fargate without managing EC2 instances
Fargate handles infrastructure provisioning

synsets.definition: Google Kubernetes Engine, a managed Kubernetes service on Google Cloud Platform
examples: Deploy to GKE for managed Kubernetes
GKE provides autopilot mode for simplified operations

synsets.definition: Azure Kubernetes Service, a managed Kubernetes service on Microsoft Azure
examples: Deploy the application to AKS
AKS integrates with Azure Active Directory

synsets.definition: a range of IP addresses in a VPC, used to segment network resources and control traffic flow
examples: Place the database in a private subnet
Public subnets have routes to the internet gateway

synsets.definition: in Kubernetes, an API object that manages external access to services in a cluster, typically HTTP/HTTPS routing
examples: Configure the ingress to route traffic to the service
The ingress controller handles SSL termination

synsets.definition: a device or service that distributes network traffic across multiple servers to ensure availability and performance
examples: The load balancer distributes requests across instances
Configure health checks on the load balancer

synsets.definition: a daemonless container engine for developing, managing, and running OCI containers, compatible with Docker commands
examples: Podman can run rootless containers
Use podman as a drop-in replacement for docker

synsets.definition: an industry-standard container runtime focused on simplicity, robustness, and portability, used by Docker and Kubernetes
examples: Kubernetes uses containerd as the container runtime
containerd manages the complete container lifecycle

synsets.definition: a package manager for Kubernetes that helps define, install, and upgrade complex Kubernetes applications using charts
examples: Install the application using helm install
Helm charts contain Kubernetes manifests and values

synsets.definition: a dedicated infrastructure layer for handling service-to-service communication, providing features like load balancing, encryption, and observability
examples: Istio is a popular service mesh
The service mesh handles mTLS between services

synsets.definition: an open-source service mesh that provides traffic management, security, and observability for microservices
examples: Deploy Istio for service mesh capabilities
Istio sidecar proxies handle inter-service communication

synsets.definition: a cloud computing execution model where the cloud provider manages server infrastructure and automatically scales resources
examples: Serverless functions scale to zero when not in use
Build serverless applications with AWS Lambda

synsets.definition: the practice of managing and provisioning infrastructure through machine-readable definition files rather than manual processes
examples: Infrastructure as code enables version control for infrastructure
IaC tools like Terraform automate provisioning

synsets.definition: AWS Cloud Development Kit, an open-source framework for defining cloud infrastructure using programming languages
examples: Define infrastructure with CDK using TypeScript
CDK synthesizes CloudFormation templates

synsets.definition: a service for storing, managing, and accessing sensitive information like API keys, passwords, and certificates
examples: Store database credentials in Secrets Manager
Rotate secrets automatically with the secret manager

synsets.definition: HashiCorp Vault, a tool for securely storing and accessing secrets, providing encryption, access control, and audit logging
examples: Store API keys in Vault
Vault supports dynamic secrets for databases

synsets.definition: a service that acts as a single entry point for APIs, handling request routing, authentication, rate limiting, and monitoring
examples: Route API requests through the API Gateway
The API Gateway handles authentication and throttling

synsets.definition: Content Delivery Network, a geographically distributed network of servers that delivers content to users based on their location
examples: Serve static assets from the CDN
The CDN reduces latency for global users

synsets.definition: AWS CloudFront, a fast content delivery network service that securely delivers data, videos, and applications globally
examples: Distribute the website through CloudFront
CloudFront integrates with S3 for origin storage

synsets.definition: Amazon Simple Queue Service, a fully managed message queuing service for decoupling and scaling microservices
examples: Send messages to the SQS queue
SQS provides at-least-once delivery

synsets.definition: Amazon Simple Notification Service, a fully managed pub/sub messaging service for application-to-application and application-to-person communication
examples: Publish notifications to the SNS topic
SNS can trigger Lambda functions

synsets.definition: AWS Route 53, a scalable domain name system (DNS) web service for routing end users to internet applications
examples: Configure DNS records in Route 53
Route 53 supports health checks and failover

synsets.definition: a virtual firewall for cloud instances that controls inbound and outbound traffic using rules
examples: Configure the security group to allow port 443
Security groups are stateful firewalls

synsets.definition: a network address translation service that enables instances in a private subnet to connect to the internet
examples: Private instances access the internet through the NAT gateway
NAT gateways provide high availability

synsets.definition: a cloud service feature that automatically adjusts the number of compute resources based on demand
examples: Auto scaling adds instances during peak traffic
Configure auto scaling policies based on CPU usage

synsets.definition: a hardened server that provides secure access to private network resources, acting as a jump host for SSH connections
examples: SSH into the bastion host to access private instances
The bastion provides audited access to the network

synsets.definition: spare cloud compute capacity offered at discounted prices that can be interrupted when capacity is needed
examples: Use spot instances for batch processing workloads
Spot instances can save up to 90% on compute costs

synsets.definition: a billing discount for committing to use specific cloud resources for a 1 or 3 year term
examples: Purchase reserved instances for predictable workloads
Reserved instances provide significant cost savings

synsets.definition: an isolated location within a cloud region, consisting of one or more data centers with independent power and networking
examples: Deploy across multiple availability zones for high availability
Each AZ has independent infrastructure

synsets.definition: a geographic area containing multiple availability zones, used to deploy cloud resources close to users or for compliance
examples: Deploy in the us-east-1 region
Choose a region based on latency requirements

synsets.definition: a deployment pattern that spans multiple availability zones for high availability and fault tolerance
examples: Enable Multi-AZ for the RDS database
Multi-AZ deployments provide automatic failover
